articles.title: Donald Trump pulls US out of Paris climate agreement
articles.author: Justine Calma
articles.summary: Donald Trump signed an executive order today to withdraw the US from the Paris climate agreement. The US is the biggest emitter of carbon dioxide emissions and the world's leading oil and gas producer. It will take one year from the date the US sends notification to the United Nations before the withdrawal will be official.

articles.title: Cold temps have taken toll across the state but warmer weather is on its way
articles.author: Parker Mancino
articles.summary: Dangerously cold temperatures are projected to continue across much of Arkansas for several days. The weather is putting vulnerable populations at risk and threatening pipes. It's also increasing the workload of those in the state's largest industry, agriculture.

articles.title: Area school closures, delays for Tuesday, Jan. 21
articles.author: Cumberland Times-News
articles.summary: Allegany County Public Schools will be closed on Tuesday, Jan. 21, 2025, due to inclement weather. Mineral County Schools are closed, non-traditional instruction day. Garrett County Public schools are closed for Tuesday and Wednesday. Hampshire County Schools is closed. Hardy County Schools will also be closed.

articles.title: Global funds to tackle climate-driven health issues grows to $7.1bn but 'still falls short'
articles.author: Rachel Kelly
articles.summary: Donors must increase their commitments to climate change to ensure funding reaches the communities that need it most, say experts and experts.   Â     “Climate’s future is in the hands of the people and communities affected by climate change.

articles.title: Mainstream Media Ignores Massive Recovery In Antarctica Sea Ice
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice in Antarctica is growing. It has shown little warming for at least 70 years. The BBC and the Financial Times used to scare people about the danger of climate change. The National Snow and Ice Data Centre (NSIDC) claims the 2016-2024 timeline 'is too short to determine that a regime shift has occurred'.

articles.title: Stormy weather affecting incomes
articles.summary: Coastal fishermen in Gelang Patah in Johor have no choice but to work in rough sea conditions and heavy rain for their survival. Fisherman Mohd Hafiza Abu Talib said the four months period from October to January is the most challenging time for the fishing community. The waters off the coast are no longer rich with marine life such as prawns and fish due to land reclamation projects. Prawns were sold for about RM60 to RM70 per kilogramme in November.

articles.title: New Study: Globally, 30% Of Modern Forests Have Not Warmed…50% Of Treelines Have Not Advanced
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: 30% of the globe's forests have not warmed in the modern era (1900s-present) and 50% have not advanced upslope. The study documents a millennia-scale treeline and temperature record from a high-elevation site in the Rocky Mountains in the USA's Rocky Mountains (Yellowstone region).

articles.title: How Environmental Factors Can Reduce Property Values
articles.author: Diego Pérez Morales
articles.summary: In the realm of real estate, environmental factors play a pivotal role in determining property value. Climate change is reshaping the real estate landscape, making certain areas less habitable and, consequently, less valuable. Properties located near sources of noise, air, or water pollution often see a decline in their market value. Risk of natural disasters, pollution, and climate change is increasing.

articles.title: Reflections – No need to tell Berks to chill out
articles.author: Mike Zielinski
articles.summary: It's been very cold in Ice Station Berks this winter. It's like we're living in a gigantic freezer. People who live on the sunny side of the street should remove seven items from their cars if they park it outside at work during Eskimo temperatures.

articles.title: Possible thunderstorms today as heatwave conditions set in across Queensland
articles.summary: Parts of Queensland will experience temperatures 5 to 7 degrees Celsius above average this week as the state is bracing for another heatwave. The weather is expected to stay warm for the rest of the week.       in the state. In the city it will be around 20 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: Weather fluctuates from freezing cold to sunny warmth
articles.summary: After a week of freezing cold, the weather in Indore has suddenly warmed up. On Monday, the maximum temperature reached 28 degrees Celsius, two degrees above normal, while the minimum temperature was 13.2 degrees Celsius. The wind speed was recorded at 20 km/h on Monday. Meteorologists warn that the end of January might bring colder weather again.

articles.title: AI Combed Millions of Images of The Arctic. It Found an Alarming Pattern.
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: The Arctic has warmed up to seven times faster than the rest of the world. Svalbard, an archipelago near the northeast coast of Greenland, is at the frontline of this climate change. If they were to completely melt tomorrow, the global sea level would rise by 1.7cm. Most of the glaciers that drain directly into the ocean have been shrinking since 1985.

articles.title: Climate Change, Hurricanes, And Emerging Vibrio Vulnificus
articles.author: John Drake
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene killed dozens of people in Florida. Five people died in Charlotte, Pasco, and Pinellas counties due to infections from Vibrio vulnificus. Florida Department of Public Health reported 83 infections statewide in 2024, of which more than half were linked to Hurricane Helene. The increasing intensity of storms and rising sea surface temperature are amplifying the scale and geographic spread of these outbreaks.

articles.title: ‘Deplorable': Canada reacts as Trump again pulls out of climate change pact
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Steven Guilbeault is in Montebello, Que. for the Liberal government's annual winter cabinet retreat. Environment minister says it's 'deplorable' that President Trump is pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord. It's not the first time Trump has pulled out of it, he did the same thing during his first term. The pact is aimed at limiting global warming to 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit (1.5 degrees Celsius) above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Moot discusses steps to address climate disasters
articles.author: Zulfiqar Baig
articles.summary: The International Rescue Committee and Pakistan Humanitarian Forum co-hosted the "Pakistan's Humanitarian Future 2025" event. The session aimed at addressing the country's preparedness and response to the escalating impacts of climate change and humanitarian crises. Pakistan contributes less than one per cent to global greenhouse gases emissions yet ranks among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable countries worldwide.

articles.title: Trump says he's withdrawing the U.S. from the Paris climate agreement again
articles.author: MATTHEW DALY
articles.summary: Trump will withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement. The United States is the world's second biggest carbon polluting nation. About half of Americans'somewhat' or'strongly' oppose U.S. action to withdraw from the climate accord. About 2 in 10 Republicans are in favor of withdrawing from the accord.

articles.title: Green skills revolution: are we ready?
articles.author: Mirza Mujtaba Baig
articles.summary: The next few decades will be crucial for climate mitigation and adaptation. According to the Paris Agreement, all countries are obligated to adhere to its provisions. Global North and South must transition their fossil fuel-dependent economies to green economies. Global demand for green skills has surged twice as fast as the available workforce. Pakistan's education in environmental management falls short of qualifications required for sustainable procurement.

articles.title: AI alone cannot save the planet
articles.author: Yana Gevorgyan
articles.summary: This year's World Economic Forum in Davos will address the theme of "Collaboration for the Intelligent Age". Ecosystems are straining under the pressure of climate change, deforestation and biodiversity loss. Augmented intelligence should be at the heart of global strategies for biodiversity conservation and climate mitigation and adaptation. Policymakers can bridge the gap between digital innovators and local environmental stewards. Businesses can align their investments with nature-positive goals and share the resulting knowledge.

articles.title: University of Winchester academic issues food warning
articles.author: Sophie Day
articles.summary: A new article in the leading scientific journal, Oxford Open Climate Change, calls for a complete overhaul of global food systems to combat climate change. The authors argue for a shift towards a primarily plant-based diet and a gradual reduction and eventual phasing out of intensive factory farming.

articles.title: Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is 'deplorable'
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: Guilbeault is in Montebello, Que. for the Liberal government's annual winter cabinet retreat. The retreat follows Trump's swearing-in ceremony in Washington. Paris agreement is a voluntary global climate pact through which nations set targets to curb their greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is 'deplorable'
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: Guilbeault is in Montebello, Que. for the Liberal government's annual winter cabinet retreat. The retreat follows Trump's swearing-in ceremony in Washington. Paris agreement is a voluntary global climate pact through which nations set targets to curb their greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is 'deplorable'
articles.author: News Staff
articles.summary: Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault is in Montebello, Que. for the Liberal government's annual winter cabinet retreat. President Trump is pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord, which is a voluntary global climate pact through which nations set targets to curb greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is 'deplorable'
articles.author: Kyle Duggan
articles.summary: President Trump is pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord. Quebec's Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault says it's 'deplorable' that he's doing that. California is experiencing one of its worst forest fire seasons ever.

articles.title: Can Trump really rename the Gulf of Mexico the Gulf of America?
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: Donald Trump wants to rename the Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America in his inaugural speech. The ocean basin is bounded by the US Gulf coast, Mexico's eastern states and the island of Cuba. It is an important centre of commerce and commerce between the US and Mexico.

articles.title: Dude, where's my snow pile? N.B. snowfall totals have been melting
articles.summary: New Brunswick's snowfall accumulations have been declining over the past few years. The annual average temperatures continue to rise in New Brunswick, which may be the reason for the decline in snowfall there.       in the last few decades.

articles.title: Study warns of a "ticking time bomb" under West Antarctic Ice Sheet as ice reveals 100+ volcanoes
articles.author: JERUSALEM POST STAFF
articles.summary: There are over 100 volcanoes beneath the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. The melting of the ice sheet accelerates processes leading to volcanic eruptions by decades to hundreds of years. Volcanic eruptions release additional heat, lava, and ash, which warm the ice, melting millions of cubic meters of ice annually. This accelerated melting could contribute to global sea level rise.

articles.title: 'US Will Exit Paris Climate Agreement Again': Trump Announces In Major Setback To Global Warming Efforts
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump withdraws the US from the Paris Climate Agreement. It's the second time in a year that the US president has pulled out of the global agreement. The US is the world's second biggest carbon dioxide emitter. It put 4.9 billion tons of CO2 in the air in 2023, down 11% from a decade earlier.

articles.title: US to withdraw from Paris agreement, expand drilling
articles.author: Issam AHMED
articles.summary: President Trump announced on Monday that the United States will withdraw from the Paris climate accord for the second time. The move is a defiant rejection of global efforts to combat planetary warming as catastrophic weather events intensify worldwide. The U.S. is not a party to the Paris accord.

articles.title: Mass of Arctic air invades parts of Canada, sends mercury plunging
articles.author: Moosejaw Today
articles.summary: A mass of cold air from the Arctic has sent temperatures plunging across parts of Canada from New Brunswick to eastern Alberta. Winds circulating from the south are to blame for the cold snap.      .   for Environment Canada's meteorologist.

articles.title: Shelby County Schools to close on Jan. 21 due to winter weather
articles.author: Noah Wortham
articles.summary: Shelby County Schools will be closed on Tuesday, Jan. 21 due to the oncoming winter weather. All extracurricular activities are canceled. Shelby County is under a cold weather advisory from 7 p.m. on Monday, January 20 through 9 a.m., January 22. NWS expects wind chills of 5 to 15 degrees and temperatures of 10 to 20 degrees.

articles.title: Letter: When will we stop killing the planet?
articles.author: Bangor Daily News
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record, as Los Angeles burned for days and scientists say "we're in a new era now" as a result of the recent climate change. Letters are verified by BDN Opinion Page staff. Send your letters to letters@bangordailynews.com

articles.title: WEF analysts have compiled a list of the biggest global risks in 2025
articles.summary: The Global Risk Report 2025 highlights the increasing uncertainty in geopolitical, environmental, social, economic, and technological areas. The report includes the results of the Global Risk Survey with assessments from over 900 experts from around the world. Most analysts expect the global outlook to be volatile over the next two years. 62% believe instability will cover the period of the next 10 years.

articles.title: Trump Says He's Withdrawing US from Paris Climate Agreement Again
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Donald Trump will withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement. It is a blow to worldwide efforts to combat global warming. The 2015 Paris agreement is voluntary and allows nations to cut their own emissions of greenhouse gases from the burning of coal, oil and natural gas. The outgoing Biden administration offered a plan to cut US greenhouse gas emissions by more than 60 per cent by 2035.

articles.title: Trump's Renewed Withdrawal from Paris Agreement: A Setback for Global Climate Efforts
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced that the United States will withdraw from the Paris climate agreement. The move distances the U.S. from international allies in the fight against global warming. Critics warn that this withdrawal signifies a setback for global climate efforts and emphasizes the urgency to participate in cutting greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Severe heatwave to spread over half of Australia this week
articles.author: system
articles.summary: A heatwave is set to spread across more than half the country this week. A cyclone spinning over waters to the west of Australia helps "block" the weather pattern and channel hot, dry winds into the west and east.   Â

articles.title: Trump says he's withdrawing the US from the Paris climate agreement again
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: The move announced Monday is a blow to worldwide efforts to combat global warming. It distances the nation from its closest allies and distances it from the world's efforts to fight climate change. It is a step away from the United States' closest allies. It's a step further away from its allies.

articles.title: Trump says he's withdrawing the US from the Paris climate agreement again
articles.author: Matthew Daly
articles.summary: President Donald Trump withdraws the United States from the Paris climate agreement. The U.S. is the world's top carbon polluting nation. The announcement comes as Trump was sworn in to a second term. In 2017, Trump announced that he would abandon the global Paris accord.

articles.title: Mass of Arctic air invades parts of Canada, sends mercury plunging
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: A mass of cold air from the Arctic has sent temperatures plunging across parts of Canada from New Brunswick to eastern Alberta. Extreme cold warnings are in effect across the country, with temperatures feeling like -40 C in parts of Alberta, -45 C in Saskatchewan and Manitoba, and down to -50 C in northern Ontario. Several schools across the Prairies and the coast of Atlantic Canada were closed because of cold weather and snow.

articles.title: Grand Strand, Pee Dee school districts adjust schedules ahead of anticipated wintry weather
articles.author: Caleb McCusker
articles.summary: School districts on the Grand Strand and in the Pee Dee are changing their schedules ahead of anticipated wintry weather this week. Caleb joined the News13 team in January 2023 after graduating from Liberty University. Caleb is a digital producer at News13 from Northern Virginia.

articles.title: Letter: When will we stop killing the planet?
articles.author: Opinion Contributor
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Wildfires are burning hotter and moving faster. Storms are getting bigger and carrying more moisture. Heat waves and drought can be devastating on their own. Al Gore warned of the increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.

articles.title: Cooper's hawk among the targets for birders on Oak Bay shores
articles.author: Oak Bay News  Staff
articles.summary: Geoffrey Newell and David Newell will lead the first Friends of Uplands Park bird walk of the year on Saturday (Jan. 25) at 9 a.m. in the main parking lot at Cattle Point. Greater Victoria is a great place for birding year-round.

articles.title: What Trump's exit from the climate deal really means
articles.author: Sara Schonhardt
articles.summary: Trump announced Monday that he will withdraw from the 2015 Paris climate agreement. The announcement collides with a rise in climate havoc around the world, including the devastating Los Angeles wildfires and revelations that last year was the hottest ever recorded. It marks the launch of an aggressive agenda to roll back U.S. climate policy driven by an emboldened president.

articles.title: Trump says he will withdraw US from Paris accord after hottest year on record
articles.author: Financial Times
articles.summary: Move deals blow to worldwide efforts to slow down global warming.    "It's a blow to the global warming effort."  "This is not the solution. It's not a solution to global warming."   'It's not the answer to climate change."

articles.title: Trump to withdraw from Paris climate agreement
articles.author: Zack Colman
articles.summary: The U.S. will withdraw from the Paris climate agreement for the second time. It's a blow to the effort to keep global temperatures from rising to dangerous levels. Nearly 200 nations agreed to take action to cut the greenhouse gases fueling stronger storms, wildfires and heatwaves.

articles.title: $17.7b climate funding gap worsens inequality in Nigeria — Oxfam
articles.author: Ernest Nzor
articles.summary: Nigeria receives only 4% of the $17.7 billion it requires annually to address climate-related disasters. The report also highlights the alarming surge in inequality in Nigeria. 75% of $4.9 billion in climate finance received between 2015 and 2021 came as loans. The resulting financial strain limits resources for critical sectors such as healthcare, education and climate resilience.

articles.title: Study warns of a "ticking time bomb" under West Antarctic Ice Sheet as ice reveals 100+ volcanoes
articles.author: JERUSALEM POST STAFF
articles.summary: A new study published in the journal Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems revealed a potential "ticking time bomb" beneath the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. There are over 100 volcanoes beneath the Antarctic ice, located along an active volcanic rift system known as West Antarctic Rift System. Volcanic eruptions release additional heat, lava, and ash, which warm the ice sheet, potentially melting millions of cubic meters of ice annually. This accelerated melting could contribute to global sea level rise, threatening coastal communities worldwide.

articles.title: Canada Invests in Climate Change Adaptation Around Ontario's Great Lakes Français
articles.author: Peter Zuzek
articles.summary: Today, the Honourable Jonathan Wilkinson and Parliamentary Secretary Julie Dabrusin announced $4.1 million in funding for two projects based around Ontario's Great Lakes under Natural Resources Canada's Climate-Resilient Coastal Communities (CRCC) Program. The CRCC Program aims to support coastal communities around the Great Lakes by completing climate change risk assessments and developing integrated adaptation plans.

articles.title: Extreme cold warnings will start to lift today as warmer air moves in
articles.author: Jodi Hughes
articles.summary: Freezing temperatures are turning around in Calgary. Jodi Hughes has a look at the five-day weather forecast from the Sky Watch Weather Centre.    iReport.com will let you know how the weather turns out in Calgary in the next few days.

articles.title: Chicago is, currently, colder than Antarctica
articles.author: Elyssa Kaufman
articles.summary: Temperatures in Chicago are in the single digits, but in Antarctica it's in the 30s. January is the warmest month in Antarctica. A cold weather advisory is in effect until noon on Monday in Chicago. The advisory will take effect again at 9 p.m. Monday until Tuesday at noon. The arctic cold is expected to stay through Wednesday.

articles.title: Would you like to work in the coldest place on Earth?
articles.summary: The BAS work in both Arctic and Antarctica to study the Earth's climate and the affects of climate change at the poles. Eloise Saville is a carpenter at Halley VI Research Station on the Brunt Ice Shelf. The starting salary is £29,273. Successful applicants will have their accommodation and food paid for by BAS.

articles.title: The problem with too many or too few people
articles.author: City News
articles.summary: Australia's total fertility rate declined from 3.55 babies per woman in 1961 to 1.5 in 2022–23. In 1947 overseas migration was seen as essential to increase living standards by developing natural resources and to increase national security. In the 2023 Intergenerational Report, Australia's population in 2062-63 was projected to be 40.5 million.

articles.title: Area school schedule changes for Tuesday and Wednesday
articles.author: Wway News
articles.summary: Bladen County Schools are moving online for Tuesday and Wednesday. Pender County Schools will be dismissing 2 hours early on Tuesday and operate on a 2 hour delay at minimum for Wednesday. The basketball games scheduled for January 21 will be postponed to a later date. Duplin County Schools dismisses at 12:00 pm on Tuesday. Calvary Christian School will be closed Tuesday.

articles.title: Australia-China ties could be 'imperilled' under Trump
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: Donald Trump's second presidential term could put Australia's relationship with China and Pacific nations at risk, expert warns.    i.e. under his second term, Donald Trump could be more hostile to Australia's relations with China, Pacific nations and other countries.

articles.title: Australia-China ties could be 'imperilled' under Trump
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: Donald Trump's second presidential term could put Australia's relationship with China and Pacific nations at risk, expert warns.    i.e. under his second term, Donald Trump could be more hostile to Australia's relations with China, Pacific nations and other countries.

articles.title: Study: Winter days on the Great Lakes growing shorter
articles.author: Duluth News Tribune
articles.summary: The Great Lakes have been losing an average of 14 days of winter conditions each decade since 1995 due to warming air. The study builds on previous research that shows winters on the Great Lakes are growing shorter due to climate change and are getting shorter each decade due to warmer air.

articles.title: Fact Check: Post shares misleading calculations about UK greenhouse gas emissions
articles.author: Reuters Fact Check
articles.summary: A Facebook post uses misleading figures and calculations to suggest the UK's contribution to climate change through carbon dioxide (CO2) and 'cow farts' is negligible. NASA climate scientist Gavin Schmidt called the post 'nonsense'. Bill Collins, a professor of atmospheric chemistry and earth system modelling at the University of Reading, said the number 3% is wrong.

articles.title: NBMCA hosting series of public meetings for floodplain mapping
articles.author: Submitted
articles.summary: The North Bay Mattawa Conservation Authority has issued a notice of public consultation period – floodplain mapping. The consultation period runs from January 20 to February 20, 2025. NBMCA is hosting a series of Public Information sessions to share the results of the floodplain map project.

articles.title: Study: Winter days on the Great Lakes growing shorter
articles.summary: The Great Lakes have been losing an average of 14 days of winter conditions each decade since 1995 due to warming air temperatures. Research has already found the Great Lakes are losing ice cover at a rate of about 5% each decade for a total loss of 25% between 1973 and 2023. The study builds on that research by focusing on changes in water temperatures during the winter months.

articles.title: How Australia's Sun Shapes Its Lifestyle
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: The sun plays a significant role in shaping the Australian lifestyle. Australia is famous for its beautiful beaches, wildlife and climate dominated by the presence of the sun. The sun influences nearly every aspect of daily life in the country.     .

articles.title: Stormy weather affecting incomes
articles.author: Story
articles.summary: Coastal fishermen in Gelang Patah in Johor report that their catch has reduced due to climate change and land reclamation projects. The waters off the coast used to be rich with marine life such as prawns and fish, but now they have to go 10 km out to Tanjung Piai to fish.

articles.title: Climate Resiliency
articles.author: Tom Yamachika
articles.summary: Hawai'i's Climate Advisory Team (CAT) recommends setting up two new funds to deal with climate change-related disasters. The Hawai'i Climate Resilience Fund, to receive $1.375 billion over five years, would fund grant programs for improvements that would increase climate resiliency, including retrofitting homes. The Disaster Recovery Fund would receive $500 million over 5 years to provide funding source for residents injured or displaced as a result of a natural disaster.

articles.title: Global economy could lose 50% of GDP by 2090 without urgent action on climate risks
articles.summary: The global economy could experience a 50% reduction in GDP between 2070 and 2090 if immediate policy measures addressing the climate crisis are not implemented. New report from the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries (IFoA) warns that existing climate targets overlook significant risks to nature and society. The report introduces a new Planetary Solvency risk dashboard.

articles.title: Ethiopia: Thousands of Families Displaced Due to Continuous Seismic Activities in Afar and Oromia
articles.summary: Some residents in Awash and Dulecha districts of Ethiopia are reluctant to evacuate due to a series of seismic activities. More than 80,000 people have been evacuated from areas that are experiencing continuous tremors, landslides and ash emissions. The displacement of nearly 400,000 livestock has disrupted the livelihoods of pastoralists.

articles.title: One Man's Opinion: So what's the big deal about Greenland?
articles.summary: Greenland is the world's largest island. It is located between the North Atlantic and Arctic oceans. Greenland is one of two autonomous territories of the Kingdom of Denmark. The capital and largest city is Nuuk, which rhymes with book. Most of Greenland's population lives near its southwest coast.

articles.title: Icy days are here again as record 762-day stretch ends
articles.author: Gordon Darroch
articles.summary: Temperatures stayed below zero at the national weather station in De Bilt on Saturday, ending a record 762-day streak without an official 'ice day'. The maximum temperature was recorded at minus 0.7C, breaking a continuous run stretching back to December 17, 2022. The previous record of 755 days was set between January 1974 and January 1976. Since records began there have been 11 years without an ice day.

articles.title: Japan's Annual Average Temperature Soars to Record High in 2024
articles.summary: In 2024, the average temperature in Japan was 1.48 degrees above the 30-year average for the period up to 2020. This is the second consecutive record high. The six highest annual averages came in the last six years. The prevailing westerly winds flowed more toward the north than usual. The highest average temperatures to date were recorded during the summer (June to August) and the autumn (September to November).

articles.title: Cherry Picking and wishful thinking?
articles.author: Bill Hammond
articles.summary: Vivek Ramaswamy is a frequent contributor to these pages. He believes that global warming is a hoax and Maine's efforts to mitigate the effects of climate change are baseless. Bill McKibben is America's foremost writer on global climate dynamics. 2024 was the hottest year in recorded history. The previous hottest year was 2023.

articles.title: Canada Invests in Climate Change Adaptation Around Ontario's Great Lakes and Delivers Update on Flood Hazard Mapping Français
articles.author: Peter Zuzek
articles.summary: Today, the Honourable Jonathan Wilkinson and Parliamentary Secretary Julie Dabrusin announced $4.1 million in funding for two projects based around Ontario's Great Lakes under Natural Resources Canada's Climate-Resilient Coastal Communities (CRCC) Program. The CRCC Program aims to support coastal communities around the Great Lakes by completing climate change risk assessments and developing integrated adaptation plans and actions.

articles.title: Former Saint Lucian Minister Takes up Role of CARICOM Climate Envoy
articles.author: Editorial Staff
articles.summary: Dr James Fletcher, former Saint Lucian Minister for Public Service, Information, Broadcasting, Sustainable Development, Energy, Science, and Technology, has been named CARICOM Climate Envoy. Dr Fletcher has earned widespread recognition as a dedicated climate change advocate. He played a pivotal role in the Caribbean's '1.5 to Stay Alive' civil society campaign focused on the need to cap global warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius to protect vulnerable regions like the Caribbean.

articles.title: Quality time with 2 species in steep decline in Connecticut
articles.author: Bill O'Brien
articles.summary: To the general public, there's probably a feeling that things overall aren't going well. Climate change, pollution, etc. affect bird populations at the species level. It's not a generalization that applies to the general population.   .

articles.title: India: Delhi sees warmest January day in six years at 26.1 degrees celsius
articles.summary: Delhi saw the highest day temperature in January in six years on Sunday. The maximum temperature was 26.1 degrees Celsius, seven notches above normal. Watch this report for more details.      Â  .   y

articles.title: Animal lover slams 'bird-brained' council for putting up warning signs
articles.author: Padma Murughappun
articles.summary: Carol Cook is angry at the council's decision to put up signs instructing visitors not to feed the wildlife at Glebe in Bowness-on-Windermere, South Cumbria. Westmorland and Furness Council defended their actions, explaining that the signs are part of efforts to educate the public on the adverse effects that feeding can have on the environment and wildlife health.

articles.title: California wildfires threaten $275 billion in agricultural losses, impacting key crops near Los Angeles
articles.summary: The wildfires currently ravaging California pose a direct threat to agriculture. The potential losses are estimated to be the highest in US history, reaching up to $275 billion. The "red flag warning" area enveloping Los Angeles includes crucial cropland. This zone is home to a substantial portion of the US avocado production, as well as significant areas dedicated to herbs, peppers, citrus, and sweet potatoes.

articles.title: Svalbard's Glaciers Are Melting Faster Than Ever Due To Climate Change
articles.author: MI News Network
articles.summary: Glaciers of Svalbard, an Arctic archipelago near Greenland, are melting down faster than ever. 91% of these glaciers have been reduced since 1985, with more than 800 km² of ice lost. The most significant retreat occurred in 2016, after a year of extreme weather, with record rainfall and unusually warm seas.

articles.title: $6m announced to protect Pictou's waterfront
articles.author: Richard Mackenzie
articles.summary: Project aims to protect Pictou waterfront from sea level rise and storm surges. The federal government is investing $2.4 million through its Disaster Mitigation and Adaptation Fund, while the provincial government is contributing $2 million and the Town of Pictou $1.6 million. The Market Wharf, which includes buildings, wooden structures, sewer, water and storm mains, roads and paths, as well as businesses and personal property, bears the brunt of the surges. Project includes a new fixed breakwater structure, a wharf extension that will be more formidable and resilient to storm surges, and the rise of structures along the waterfront.

articles.title: Environment minister says Donald Trump pulling out of Paris pact is "deplorable"
articles.author: Kyle Duggan
articles.summary: Steven Guilbeault is in Montebello, Que. for the Liberal government's annual winter cabinet retreat. He criticizes President Donald Trump for pulling the U.S. out of the 2015 Paris Accord. Guil beault points out that Trump did the same thing during his first term in office.

articles.title: How Australians Beat the Heat in Scorching Summers
articles.author: Nelleke van Niekerk
articles.summary: During the summer months in Australia, temperatures can soar, particularly in the interior and northern parts of the country. The heat can be relentless, with temperatures frequently exceeding 40°C (104°F) and posing challenges for everyday life.  .

articles.title: Lesotho: Climate Change Threatens Livestock Farming
articles.author: Mathatisi Sebusi
articles.summary: The future of farming in Lesotho is under threat due to climate change. Communities report significant challenges, as crops, vegetables, and livestock are deteriorating due to water scarcity and degraded rangelands. Since 2022, the region has experienced persistent drought, leading to a decline in wool, mohair, and milk production. Chief Tšangoane Sehahle's farming-dependent community is struggling due to the drought.

articles.title: Effects Of 1.5°C Global Warming In Switzerland And Beyond
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: This year we could exceed the symbolic threshold of 1.5–1.5C of global warming for the first time. Here's why this limit matters and what crossing it could mean for life on Earth on Earth.   .   "This is why it matters"

articles.title: Ethiopia: Pastoralist Communities in Afar Reluctant to Evacuate Amid Earthquakes, Citing Livestock Concerns - Authorities Consider Mandatory Relocation
articles.summary: Some residents in Awash and Dulecha districts of Oromia are reluctant to evacuate, because they are concerned about their livestock and property. The government is evacuating over 60,000 people from high-risk areas to safer locations. People displaced by the recent earthquakes in the Afar region are struggling to survive in overcrowded shelters, facing severe shortages of food, water and essential supplies.

articles.title: Tanzania: Pemba's Woman Salt Farmers Forge Livelihoods Amid Climate Woes
articles.author: Kizito Makoye
articles.summary: For female artisanal salt farmers in Tanzania's Pemba archipelago, salt production is both their livelihood and their struggle. Rising sea levels, erratic rainfall, and intensifying heat are putting their enterprise at risk. Experts believe output could triple with better tools, but resources remain scarce.

articles.title: New reports reveal unexpected shift in marine life off the coast of California: 'I've seen a lot of change here'
articles.author: Jeremiah Budin
articles.summary: There are more and more whales swimming near the Southern California coast because of warmer ocean waters. The Marine Mammal Protection Act was passed a year before the Endangered Species Act in 1972. Some whale species are having trouble finding food and making their migratory trips because of the changes.

articles.title: Scientists puzzled by unexpected discovery while analyzing heavy rainfall patterns — here's what they found
articles.author: Chelsea Cook
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise, extreme rainfall events become more frequent and more intense. The most significant increases are occurring in tropical regions such as India, Northern Australia and the Amazon. Heavier rainfall puts a strain on water management systems and raises the chances of waterborne diseases. Governments are investing in flood defenses, sustainable drainage systems and green infrastructure to reduce flood risks.

articles.title: NiMet to release 2025 climate prediction February 4
articles.author: Makua Ubanagu
articles.summary: The Nigerian Meteorological Agency will unveil its 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction on February 4, 2025. The presentation will provide critical climate-related forecasts for the year. The Minister of Aviation and Aerospace Development, Mr. Festus Keyamo SAN, is expected to perform the official presentation.

articles.title: Ask Dr. Universe: Global warming is melting the ice polar bears depend on
articles.author: The Spokesman-Review
articles.summary: Maeve, 7, wonders why polar bears depend on melting sea ice. The sea ice that occurs over the Arctic Ocean is the reason why they are so powerful and beautiful. Washington State University explains it's due to their dependence on the sea ice over the ocean.

articles.title: Dennis Glen Morrell: Let's stick to the facts about climate change
articles.summary: Russell Cook's Jan. 9 response to Joe Silverman's column 'Climate in the court of public opinion' focused on climate change issues long since debunked. Global warming has led to a changing Arctic environment and changing military reality, with China and Russia competing with the U.S. for domination of the region.

articles.title: Ask Dr. Universe: Global warming is melting the ice polar bears depend on
articles.summary: Maeve, 7, wonders why the ice that polar bears depend on is melting because of global warming. The Arctic is warming two to four times faster than anywhere else on Earth. If the snow and ice can't recover, polar bears could lose two-thirds of their population.

articles.title: The Carolinas still need help 4 months after Hurricane Helene. A Florence group is stepping up.
articles.author: Chris Day
articles.summary: Cooks for Christ is holding a chicken bog benefit on Jan. 23 to raise money for Hurricane Helene relief efforts in the Carolinas. The hurricane caused major damage in South and North Carolina. The money will go to Samaritan's Purse to help those affected by Helene.

articles.title: Succession star Brian Cox worried women are ‘being marginalised' in America
articles.author: Hannah Roberts
articles.summary: 'The Oscars could be used to put some kind of hidden protest in who we are and what we are against and why global warming is a major issue,' he says.      .   "I think that the one thing that we could do during the Oscars, is to actually put some hidden protest'

articles.title: National Penguin Day 2025 Date and Significance: Everything To Know About the Day That Aims To Raise Awareness About the Conservation of Penguins
articles.author: Kabir
articles.summary: National Penguin Day is celebrated across the United States of America (USA) on January 20. The annual event aims to raise awareness about the protection and conservation of penguins. Penguins are flightless birds that inhabit the Southern Hemisphere, primarily in Antarctica. They are also found in regions like South America, South Africa, New Zealand, and Australia. Many penguin species face threats due to climate change.

articles.title: Understanding the Impact of Climate Change on Global Agriculture
articles.author: Riverbender Staff
articles.summary: Agriculture is the backbone of many economies, providing food, raw materials, and employment to billions of people worldwide. Around 1 billion people are employed in agriculture and it accounts for about 10% of global GDP. Climate change poses significant challenges to global agriculture, but also presents opportunities for innovation and transformation.

articles.title: Photo Essay: Kashmir's Ingenious Climate-Responsive Architecture.
articles.author: Umar Manzoor Shah
articles.summary: There are projections of a 2°C global temperature increase. Extreme weather events such as floods, droughts, and cyclones are already becoming more common in India. In Kashmir, the average maximum temperature in Srinagar rose by 1.05°C between 1980–1999 and 2000–2019, and the winter of 2023–2024 was the driest on record.

articles.title: Part 3: The impact of climate change on Puerto Rico
articles.summary: The PR Climate Plan describes the impacts of climate change and steps needed to protect the citizenry and move toward sustainability in various sectors. Puerto Rico is still 96% fossil-fuel powered, but efforts are underway to shift away from fossil fuels and reduce our contribution to atmospheric carbon dioxide.

articles.title: ⚡Do Penguins Mate for Life? Researchers Discover Phillip Island Penguins Face Rising Divorce Rates
articles.summary: Phillip Island's penguins divorce their partners after a poor breeding season. Phillip Island houses the world's largest colony of aquatic birds. Here's all you need to know about the study and the study's findings.   .   and its results.

articles.title: NiMet To Unveil 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction February 4
articles.author: Udeze Ekene
articles.summary: The Nigerian Meteorological Agency (NiMet) will present 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction to the public on Tuesday, February 4th. The Minister of Aviation and Aerospace Development, Festus Keyamo, will perform the presentation of the publication. The document includes the onset and cessation dates of the 2025 rainy season and the length of the cropping season.

articles.title: Geraldton residents take to the beach to cool off as city records equal hottest day on record at 49.3C
articles.summary: Geraldton residents take to the beach to cool off as city records equal hottest day on record at 49.3C, as it's 49C at the beach. It's the hottest day in Geraldton since records began in 1881. It was 49C that day.

articles.title: Coalition Urges Vic Premier to Halt 2025 Duck Season
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Laurie Levy is calling on the Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan to cancel the 2025 recreational duck shooting season due to the risk of spreading the H5N1 avian influenza virus. The virus is devastating penguins and other species in Antarctica. Five of the eight species classified as "game" ducks show significant population declines.

articles.title: Evolution going into reverse, says Attenborough. Also, Trump sworn in.
articles.summary: Sir David Attenborough has presented a paper to the International Science Gang. He claims that evolution is going backwards and that the rise of people like Trump, Musk and Tate is a sure sign of this. Professor Brian Cox thinks that human beings do not have the upper body strength to climb trees any more.

articles.summary: is forecast for Perth this afternoon. The mercury will reach a record high temperature. The heat is expected to reach 30 degrees. The sun will be hot in Perth. The weather is forecast to be warm and sunny in the afternoon. It will be very hot.

articles.title: Pemba's Woman Salt Farmers Forge Livelihoods Amid Climate Woes
articles.summary: For Salma Mahmoud Ali and other female artisanal salt farmers in Tanzania's Pemba archipelago, salt production is both their livelihood and their struggle. Rising sea levels put their enterprise at risk. Rising temperatures accelerate evaporation, often causing salt to crumble before it can be harvested. Unpredictable rainfall, once a seasonal certainty, now floods the ponds without warning, washing away weeks of labor.

articles.title: Earth's water cycle is shifting dramatically and it's not good news
articles.summary: Nasa study confirms that Earth's water cycle is shifting in unprecedented ways. The shift is largely attributed to human activities, including agriculture. They gathered remote sensing data from 2003 to 2020 from several Nasa satellite sources. The assessment is based on nearly 20 years of satellite observations. The research is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

articles.title: Make sure your pets are part of your bushfire survival plan
articles.author: Contributed
articles.summary: CFA and RSPCA Victoria are urging residents to include pets in their bushfire survival plans, amid the significant fire activity already impacting the state this summer, and they are urging people to include their pets in the survival plans as well. The state is seeing a lot of bushfire activity.

articles.title: Billionaire wealth rises $3 trillion in 2024, at a rate three times faster than year before, Oxfam finds
articles.author: Rachel Clayton
articles.summary: Elon Musk remains the world's richest person. Global billionaire wealth grew by $3 trillion last year, equivalent to $8.4 billion a day. Australia's 47 billionaires make an average of A$67,000 an hour, 1300 times higher than the average worker. Gina Rinehart remains Australia's richest with a net worth of $47.3 billion. Andrew Forrest is Australia's second richest, worth A$29.2 billion, and Harry Triguboff is third.

articles.title: More Cold Truth About Global Warming
articles.author: I Editorial Board
articles.summary: Donald Trump's inauguration was moved inside due to the bitter cold weather in Washington. The temperature in the capital at today's swearing-in at noon is predicted to be 22 degrees. This is far from the coldest ever, which was 5 degrees when Ronald Regan took office in 1985. The warmest day in inauguration history reached 55 degrees. John F. Kennedy's 1961 ceremony was preceded by 8 inches of snow.

articles.title: Armed conflict is this year's most urgent threat to our world, global leaders say
articles.author: Heather Stewart
articles.summary: Escalating armed conflict is the most urgent threat for world in 2025. Extreme weather events, biodiversity loss, 'critical changes to Earth systems', and natural resource shortages are the second-most common risks. Misinformation and disinformation came next on the list of threats, followed by 'adverse outcomes of AI technologies'. This year's Davos meeting takes place in the shadow of Trump's inauguration.

articles.title: Perth to swelter through blistering summer heat as mercury nears record of 44.5C
articles.author: Perth Now
articles.summary: Temperatures in Perth hit 40.6C and Swanbourne is at 41.9C. Monday is forecast to be the hottest day of the week with temperatures between 38C and 41C. A heatwave warning has been issued for more than half of WA. There is also a high fire warning for the lower half of the State.

articles.title: Australian billionaires earn $67,000 an hour, over 1300 times more than average workers
articles.author: Demi Huang
articles.summary: 47 Australian billionaires earn $67,000 an hour, while the average hourly wage is about $51. The richest Australians' combined wealth increased by more than 8 per cent, or $28 billion, in 2024. 35 per cent of Australian billionaires' wealth is inherited, with a significant portion linked to the historic and ongoing impacts of colonialism. Five billion people live below the World Bank poverty line.

articles.title: '47 Australians Earn $67,000 per Hour – Implications for Society'
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: The world's 10 richest people added $150 million to their wealth each day in 2024. Australia's 47 billionaires increased their wealth by a combined $28 billion last year, at a collective rate of $3.2 million per hour. An oligarchy is taking shape in America of extreme wealth and power.

articles.title: As the world warms, Davos braces for political drama
articles.author: International New York Times
articles.summary: The last year was the warmest in recorded history. Each of the 10 hottest years on record has come in the past decade. The World Economic Forum has identified extreme weather as one of the top global risks. The heat is now inescapable, according to the WHO.

articles.title: Scientists confirm 2024 as warmest year on record
articles.author: Guardian Nigeria
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization has confirmed that 2024 is the warmest year on record, based on six international datasets. The past ten years have all been in the Top Ten, in an extraordinary streak of record-breaking temperatures. The global average surface temperature was 1.55 °C above the 1850-1900 average. This is the first calendar year with a global mean temperature of more than 1.5°C.

articles.title: Million-year-old ice drilling for crucial climate data
articles.summary: Australian scientists in Antarctica have began extracting an ice core to record climate data. They hope to reach a depth of 3100m and uncover ice more than one million years old by the summer of 2028/29. The team travelled through blizzards and heavy snow to bring 62 tonnes of equipment to the site.

articles.title: Million-year-old ice drilling for crucial climate data
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: Bubbles of air trapped in the ice provide the most detailed record of how the Earth's atmosphere and climate have changed, says Dr. Richard Bruegher.   He says bubbles of air, along with natural and man-made chemical markers, provide a detailed record.

articles.title: Rare G3 Atlas comet lights up Adelaide skies in a once-in-160,000-year event
articles.author: Lauren Thomson
articles.summary: The G3 Atlas comet is visible in the Southern Hemisphere as it passes overhead in Adelaide. It will be with us for a short time before continuing its orbit into the galaxy and fading from view from January 23. It is one of the brightest comets to pass Earth in the last 20 years and the third brightest ever recorded according to RAS.

articles.title: Newly-discovered comet visible in Adelaide skies in rare event
articles.summary: The G3 Atlas comet is visible in the Southern Hemisphere as it passes overhead in Adelaide. It will be with us for a short time before continuing its orbit into the galaxy and fading from view from January 23. It is one of the brightest comets to pass Earth in the last 20 years and the third brightest ever recorded according to RAS.

articles.title: Extreme cold stretches across Ontario until Wednesday
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Environment Canada has issued extreme cold warnings for most of Ontario. The weather agency has also issued a snow squall warning for Northern Huron County and surrounding areas, which is expected to bring 30 to 60 centimetres of snow until Wednesday. The agency warns people to check on older relatives, neighbours and friends and to keep pets indoors.

articles.title: At the mercy of climate change
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: The sixth assessment report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) finds that because of human activity, the climate is changing rapidly and presents a range of new risks and vulnerabilities for rural people. The report also finds that the global warming is due to human activity.

articles.title: Editorial: Protect Long Island's natural treasures
articles.author: Tbr Staff
articles.summary: There are 9 million people living in the Long Island Sound watershed, 1.5 million of them in Suffolk County. The large population puts pressure on the sewer systems, which if ineffective, affect water quality. Suffolk County Water Quality Restoration Act was passed last year. It will provide the county with $4 billion to upgrade the water infrastructure.

articles.title: At the mercy of climate change
articles.author: Nasir Ali Panhwar
articles.summary: Because of human activity, global temperatures have increased by 1.1°C compared to temperature in the pre-industrial era. This increase is projected to reach or exceed 1.5°C within the next 20 years. Climate change has profound effects on agricultural systems and on the livelihoods of rural people who depend on them. Rural people are particularly vulnerable to the adverse impacts of climate change due to the importance of climate-dependent agriculture, high rates of poverty and food insecurity.

articles.title: Aussie quest for the oldest ice to unlock Earth's ancient climate puzzle
articles.summary: Australian Antarctic Program scientists are drilling to find the oldest, continuous ice core record of Earth's climate. Palaeoclimate scientist Dr Joel Pedro said the information is captured in bubbles of air held by snow falling across the centuries. It has taken the past two years to set up the Dome C North site for the project, with 62 tonnes of equipment carried through blizzards and heavy snow by two snow-groomers and six tractors.

articles.title: Aussie quest for the oldest ice to unlock Earth's ancient climate puzzle
articles.author: Ayden Dawkins
articles.summary: Scientists are hunting for an ice core that could unlock a puzzle millions of years in the making. They are looking for the ice core in the Australian outback. It could be found in the Bering Strait.    i.e. in the ocean floor.

articles.title: Aussie quest for the oldest ice to unlock Earth's ancient climate puzzle
articles.summary: Australian scientists are drilling to find the oldest, continuous ice core record of Earth's climate. Palaeoclimate scientist Dr Joel Pedro said the information is captured in bubbles of air held by snow falling across the centuries. It has taken the past two years to set up the Dome C North site for the project.

articles.title: Aussie quest for the oldest ice to unlock Earth's ancient climate puzzle
articles.summary: Australian scientists are drilling to find the oldest, continuous ice core record of Earth's climate to reveal the secrets of how the atmosphere and climate have changed. Palaeoclimate scientist Dr Joel Pedro said the information is captured in bubbles of air held by snow falling across the centuries. It took the past two years to set up the Dome C North site for the project.

articles.title: Svalbard's Glaciers Have Lost an Area the Size of Manhattan Into the Sea
articles.summary: The Arctic has warmed up to seven times faster than the global average since 1979. Svalbard, an archipelago near the northeast coast of Greenland, is at the frontline of this climate change. More than half of Svalard is covered by glaciers. Most of them are losing mass through iceberg calving. They also retreat in the summer and advance in winter.

articles.title: 8 places likely to be underwater by the end of the century
articles.summary: By the end of the century, some famous landmarks could be underwater due to climate change. The Maldives is the lowest-lying nation in the world, with an average ground elevation of 1.5 meters above sea level. Venice, Italy is more vulnerable to flooding due to land subsidence and rising sea levels. New Orleans faces a high risk of storm surges due to its below-sea-level elevation and surrounding waters. Bangkok is experiencing a swift decline due to groundwater depletion and escalating urban development. The Seychelles islands are in danger of sinking.

articles.title: Dutton's approach to leadership is leaving a sour taste for some
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: Peter Duttons focus is on sowing discord and not on the real and critical issues. His policies do not address climate change, environmental repair, social service needs or growing wealth disparities. The insurance and reinsurance markets are global so premiums will rise due to the LA fires, Spanish floods and other climate disasters.

articles.title: Australian billionaires make $67,000 an hour, Oxfam says in call for tax on super-rich
articles.author: Cait Kelly
articles.summary: 47 billionaires in Australia earn an average of A$67,000 an hour, 1,300 times more than the average Australian. Gina Rinehart and Andrew Forrest are the two richest people in Australia. Oxfam is calling for a modest wealth tax on the super-rich.

articles.title: SAP BrandVoice: Will AI And Climate Risk Management Align In 2025?
articles.author: Sophia Mendelsohn
articles.summary: There's no instant feedback switch that turns off climate disasters once the world hits its emissions targets. Long-term business forecasting must account for an increase in climate shocks. Businesses that are more vulnerable to climate risks pay more in insurance premiums. Sustainability transcends mere risk mitigation and is fundamental to organizational resilience and strategic advantage.

articles.title: Scientists push for swift intervention to shield coasts from storm surges and rising seas
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: Sea levels are expected to rise between 50 and 100 centimeters by 2100 and violent storms to become more frequent, so swift intervention is needed to minimize the risk of flooding along the Catalan coast.    Researchers at the Blanes Center for Advanced Studies (CEAB-CSIC) and UPC Barcelona are warning about the issue.

articles.title: One Man's Opinion: So What's The Big Deal About Greenland
articles.author: Morgan Citizen
articles.summary: Iceland is actually quite green and Greenland is largely a slab of ice, though it's not as icy as it used to be. In high school geography, Iceland was purposefully deceptively named and is quite green, whereas Greenland is mainly a huge slab of snow.

articles.title: Earth's north magnetic pole is on move again
articles.author: The Spokesman-Review
articles.summary: Earth's north magnetic pole is moving toward Siberia. The current behaviour of magnetic north is something that we have never observed before. Since at least the early 19th century, the pole has been situated in the Canadian Arctic. Now, after a recent acceleration, it is closer to Siberia than to Canada.

articles.title: Solana Beach climate commission gets name change
articles.author: San Diego Union-Tribune
articles.summary: The Solana Beach Climate Action Commission will be called the Climate and Resiliency Commission. The commission was formed in 2015. Its focus will shift to implementation of the CAP Update mitigation measures and the concentration on adaptation and resiliency, according to the council's decision.

articles.title: Israeli Minister Accuses Australia's Labor of ‘Ineffectual Response' Against Antisemitism
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Sharren Haskel has blamed Australia's current leadership for a spike in antisemitism in the country. Haskel made the statement on X following a high-level meeting with Australia's Labor Attorney-General Mark. Mark is a senior member of the Australian Labor Party.

articles.title: Forty-one species added to Australia's threatened list despite zero extinction target
articles.author: system
articles.summary: A number of animals, plants and an entire ecosystem were added to Australia's extinction watch list in 2024. We look at the new species under threat in this video series.    i.e. a new species of animal, plant or ecosystem that is under threat.

articles.title: The scourge of global warming
articles.author: Laurel Leader-Call
articles.summary: Scientists announced that 2024 will be the hottest year on record. Los Angeles burned for days on end and scientists made the announcement as a result of the heat from the fires there.      .   i   in this article.

articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Kiki Morris is an Indigenous model and former Bachelor star. She wants the date of Australia Day to be changed from January 26 to January 1st. The date marks when the First Fleet arrived in Sydney in 18th century.   Â

articles.title: Frightening Memories of Project Ice-worm: Militarization and the Future of the Arctic Region
articles.author: Global Research
articles.summary: Increasing militarization and resource exploitation is not good news for ecologically sensitive and vulnerable region. Arctic region is warming at twice the global rate, leading to rapid melting of ice. USA's intentions of buying/annexing Greenland are a serious concern for environmentalists.

articles.title: Australia's 1,400-year-old mystery ‘earth rings' point to 65,000 years of tradition
articles.author: Interesting Engineering
articles.summary: A chain of unexplained rings rises from the Sunbury hills at the fringe of Melbourne, Australia. The earth rings are not a natural formation but evidence of human effort. They depict Ancient Aboriginal people and their ongoing connection to the Country.

articles.title: Why don't Australians source more coffee from our region?
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Australia imports most of its coffee from the other side of the world. Climate change and coffee bean prices are skyrocketing. Australia is surrounded by coffee-growing countries like Papua New Guinea and Indonesia, but it imports it from other countries.

articles.title: Illinois affected by a record number of billion-dollar climate disasters in 2024, mostly severe storms
articles.author: Chicago Tribune
articles.summary: California's wildfires and last year's destructive hurricanes in the Southeast are frightening examples of the dramatic impacts of climate change. Illinoisans might feel relatively safe from these devastating events, but recently released data shows no region is truly immune to weather disasters. In 2024, in 2024,

articles.title: Svalbard's Glaciers Have Lost an Area the Size of Manhattan Into the Sea
articles.author: The Maritime Executive
articles.summary: The Arctic has warmed nearly four times faster than the global average since 1979. Svalbard, an archipelago near the northeast coast of Greenland, is at the frontline of this climate change. More than half of it is covered by glaciers. If they don't change, it will get worse.

articles.title: As Trump is inaugurated, victims of Los Angeles fires fear no help from the government
articles.summary: At least 27 people have died in a series of wildfires in Southern California. The fires destroyed over 40,000 acres of land and nearly 15,000 structures. Trump's inauguration on Monday symbolizes the emergence of reactionary forces determined to deny science and roll back even the minimal climate measures put in place by previous administrations. The WSWS spoke to Altadena residents impacted by the fires.

articles.title: Great Lakes Have Lost 25% of Ice Cover Since 1973
articles.author: Danielle Kaeding
articles.summary: The Great Lakes have been losing an average of 14 days of winter conditions each decade since 1995 due to warming air temperatures. Research has already found the Great Lakes are losing ice cover at a rate of about 5% each decade for a total loss of 25% between 1973 and 2023.

articles.title: Summer sand grab: entitled Aussies are coming in hot
articles.author: Paul Scott
articles.summary: Summer sun rises with menace over the Australian coastline. By 7am, city beaches can already display a tableau of territorial ambition. The sands of this great southern land begin their transformation into a battlefield as the heat climbs. The beach is full of towels, shade tents, beach umbrellas, folding chairs and cabanas.
